content.text:
Provide one single-word clue that relates to some of your team's words from the list below. You can choose to how many and to which words your clue relates to.
The goal is to have your partner guess all of your team's words based on the clues you give them, before the other team has uncovered all of theirs. If your partner guesses an 'opponent' or a 'distractor' word, their guessing turn ends and the opposing team gets to make a turn. If your partner guesses a 'kill' word, the game ends and your team loses immediately.
The more words your clue relates to, the quicker you can win the game, but the harder the associations may be to guess for your partner, so choose your clue word wisely. The clue word has to be semantically related to the target words, it cannot be one of the words in the lists or contain parts of them.

Always give your single-word clue and your comma-separated list of related target words in the following format and make your answers as short as possible, never include any other text than is required in this form:

CLUE: <WORD>
TARGETS: <TARGETS>

Your team words are: bank, boom, scrub, pit, duck, hop, bust, ham, shock.
Your opponent's team words are: lean, chase, file, toll, counter, beetle, flat, shower.
Distractor words are: flaw, flip, sap, drill, pry, sheet, jog.
The kill words are: chip.

Let me evaluate which clue might be best based on number of connections and risk of incorrect guesses:

4. drill - Drilling is a common operation in quarries to extract stone or set explosives. Strong connection.
5. flaw - Might refer to flaws in stone or rock, but not as direct as some others.
6. toll - Could refer to the toll or impact of quarrying on the environment, but this is somewhat indirect.
7. pry - Prying might be used to loosen rocks, but it's not as central to quarrying as drilling or pit.

Based on this analysis, the strongest connections to "quarry" appear to be:
1. pit - Most direct, as a quarry is often described as a type of pit
2. drill - Very relevant to quarrying operations

Since I can only choose one word, I'll go with "pit" as it's the most direct definition-related connection.

So my guess will be: pit

content.text: GUESS: pit
